responses.content: Replay of the conference call will be available on the investor relations site.
Q1 revenue grew 12% to $14.9B, cloud revenue grew 28%, and we delivered $455B of RPO—up 359% year-over-year—based on new AI contracts.

OCI consumption revenue was up 57%. Demand continues to outstrip supply, yet we are turning capacity over in about a week and plan to deliver 71 multi-cloud regions while investing in partner datacenters.
We expect FY26 CapEx around $35B; we deploy revenue-generating equipment just before customers accept it, so higher capex immediately feeds future revenue.
Oracle is the custodian of the world’s most valuable private data, and our new Oracle AI Database vectorizes that data so it can be read by LLMs securely, enabling enterprise AI inferencing at scale.

Owning silicon, networking, infrastructure, database, and applications lets us solve problems at every layer, deliver faster, more reliable systems, and offer AI-generated application suites that competitors can’t match.

questions.question_text: Can you explain the drivers behind the $455B RPO surge and how much infrastructure reinvestment is required to service it?
With AI transforming computing, why does Oracle’s control of the full stack from silicon through apps remain a strategic advantage?
How should investors think about the ramp in CapEx/unit costs relative to revenue as you build more GPU-heavy capacity?
How do you keep the AI training business differentiated and profitable even if training demand moderates?
How quickly can enterprise customers adopt the Oracle AI Database for inferencing, and how does capacity constraints affect that rollout?
